captions.text:
Physics, at its most basic, is just a description
of the motion of the stuff in our universe.

“This planet goes this way, that rocket
goes that way” – except that some – in

fact, many – objects move without moving.
Or, more precisely, they move without going
anywhere.

I’m talking objects that spin, revolve,
rotate, pirouette, orbit, circle, gyrate,

whirl, twirl, cartwheel, and so on. Like a
planet around a star, an electron in an atom,

or even our solar system going around the
gravitational center of the milky way: from

up close they’re certainly moving, but in
the grand scheme of things, that motion doesn’t
take them anywhere.

We can still talk about it, though: just like
“momentum” is a concept that describes

how much oomph an object has when it moves
in a straight line, “angular momentum”

is a way to account for how much oomph objects
have when they’re going in circles – figuratively,
or literally.

And angular momentum is simple, in theory:
pick a point, any point. Pretend your object

is moving in a circle around that point. Figure
out how fast the object is moving along the

circle (never mind that it probably isn’t
moving exactly along the circle, and that

the circle might have to change size over
time to follow the object), then multiply

that speed times the size of the circle and
the object’s mass, and there you have it:
angular momentum.

For example, a 2 kilogram 60 cm-diameter bicycle
wheel going 20 km per hour would have an angular

momentum of about 7 kilogram meters squared
per second.

The reason we care about angular momentum
is that if you take a bunch of objects that

are interacting electromagnetically or gravitationally
or whatever, and add up all of their angular

momenta into one number, then that total value
won’t change over time (unless some other

objects from outside come in and mess things
up).

So earth, which is 150 million kilometers
from the sun, orbits at 30 km/s and has a

mass of 6*10^24 kilograms, has an angular
momentum of 2.7 * 10^40 kilogram meters squared

per second. That’s four thousand quintillion
quintillion bicycle wheels! And this angular

momentum stays roughly constant over the course
of the earth’s orbit year in and year out.

But what’s amazing is that even if the sun
and the rest of the solar system were to suddenly

disappear, the earth would STILL have that
same angular momentum about the point where

the sun WAS. Without the sun’s gravity,
the earth would of course now move in a straight

line, requiring an ever-larger imaginary circle
as it got farther from the point where the

sun used to be. But as the earth continued
through space, its 30km/s velocity would also

point less and less along the circle, so when
you calculated the angular momentum, the decrease

in velocity would exactly cancel out the increase
in the size of the circle, and you’d always

get the same answer. 2.7 * 10^40 kilogram
meters squared per second.

So even when nothing is rotating at all, angular
momentum is still conserved. And that’s

the beauty of a law of physics – it works
even when you try to break it!

comments.author: Tim S

comments.text:
L comes from the "right hand rule" of vector cross products r x p=L. Since 
r and p are in the x-y plane, they are perpendicular to each other and form 
an "L" shape﻿

comments.author: UnderscoreZeroLP

comments.text:
+UnderscoreZeroLP Because in algebra, X is a variable and it would be 
really hard to look at with all those X's. An example of the hard way, X 
x X = X^2. An example of the easy way, X * X = X^2. Simpler, yeah?
comments.author: hellbreaker6666

comments.text: +UnderscoreZeroLP It's not really a decimal, more of a floating period.
comments.author: TreeOfMusic

comments.text:
Because "." Is a scalar product and "×" or "^" is a vector product. In 
advanced Physics and Mathematics it's important to make this distinction. 
The "×" is used in formulae like the torque formula (τ = F × d) since you 
are multiplying two perpendicular vector quantities to get a third vector 
perpendicular to both of them (the direction of the torque is defined by 
the right-hand "cork-screw" or "grip" rule)
comments.author: atrumluminarium

comments.text:

When we are kids we use the x.
comments.author: Pablo García Béltran

comments.text:
Generally you use neither one for basic multiplication, they would just be 
put together with parentheses separating them. The X denotes vector cross 
products and the dot scalar dot products.

children, if you have to daily deal with mathematical symbols and numbers

years, I don't know about other countries, but right here that's how it is.

comments.text:
+MinutePhysics (or anyone else who has the answer) As far as velocity is 
concerned, why would the earth's velocity decrease as a result of the lack 
of the sun's influence? On one hand, I think of newton's second law of 
inertia which describes moving bodies as moving at constant velocities, 
unless acted on by an unbalanced force. In this case, wouldn't an 
unbalanced force be something outside the designated system, thus altering 
the angular momentum? Conversely, Kepler's law describes the velocity of a 
planet as a function of the distance the planet is to the sun, but in the 
absence of the sun's influence, wouldn't this not be applicable? I haven't 
dealt with angular momentum yet in my Physics class so I don't fully 
understand it.  ﻿

comments.text:
Correct me if I'm wrong but doesn't the sun also have an angular momentum? 
The east isn't exactly rotating about the sun. Both the sun and the earth 
are rotating about the centre of mass of the earth-sun system (which just 
so happens to be within the surface of the sun). But in this case the sum 
of the angular momentum of the earth and the sun should be a constant and 
won't change over time. But the individual values of L can and should 
change because the orbit is elliptical.﻿
